review_title: Don't Be Wooed by the Food
years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: TuckShop serves up the best food in the Bay Area. Great benefits including health, dental, vision, commuter subsidy, cell phone, health/wellness subsidy, and more. cons:
Don't let the food distract you from what is going on. I was merely hired as a diversity box to check. Upper level leadership states that diversity and inclusion are "important" and a "high-priority" but in researching the trends of POCs and women in the Dropbox workplace, you will see that there are major swings, not allowing for POCs to get comfortable in the workplace. You will also be paid less than your counterparts who are in the same role, with the same level of experience but display a less diverse demographic background. ERGs were great to find community in but that message needs to not only be a safe space to find community but it should mean something to upper level leadership. 

Dropbox promotes people into positions of power who have never lead a team before and who should never be allowed the opportunity to offer guidance to other human beings. There is zero intention behind the hiring and separation process which directly displays the patriarchal, "Boy's Club," stigma of the Bay Area Tech Industry.

If you want to make an impact here, I highly suggest knowing someone higher up and not deviating from their ideologies. New and differing ideas are not welcomed from my understanding.

There is also not a very clear direction that this product is heading in. There are multiple different value propositions, giving employees the feeling of having their hands in too many buckets at one time. There is also no clarity on who to turn to when trying to problem solve.
advice_to_mgmt: Be intentional about your hiring and promotion process. Often times length of service, age, traditional tech industry demographics, or technical acumen does not directly correlate to high quality leadership. Hiring people that are different from you may actually benefit the overall camaraderie of your organization and provide a higher ability to achieve greatness.

review_title: Large Company with large company strengths and weaknesses
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time
pros:
Great benefits
Tuck Shop food is really good. The Wellness Benefit is large and you can use it on a very wide variety of equipment and services. Company matches donations up to a certain amount.

Work Environment 
Newish building with many different work areas. Day to day functions are well organized so that you have relatively little administrative unpleasantness. An awesome Dropstop on every floor takes care of IT needs promptly.

Pockets of Engineering Excellence 
Some parts of the engineering organization are strong: Magic Pocket, sync, and machine learning stand out. Hack Week lives on.

HelloSign Acquisition
The company may have realized that it is organizationally/culturally not equipped to grow organically and now seems willing to acquire for growth.
cons:
Weak Strategic Thinking
"Evolving" strategy as each year's strategy proved to not work. Each year's strategy is based on models of the industry where either the model is unconvincing or it is not at all clear why Dropbox's approach is the winning one.

Passive Aggressive Culture
People are always friendly face to face but beneath the veneer there is a lot of jockeying for power. Power distribution is evident when prizes projects get done by in power teams even though the area is theoretically another team's area of responsibility. People assign overflow tasks to other people even though they are responsible for it. People initially promise to do work and then shirk it without repercussions.

Politics
Ultimately unsuccessful projects were created and pushed out the door to get people promoted. Many people jump on board early on and generate immediately ridiculous shoddy user research to back up the work. Shallow technology is hyped as awesome and weak initial indicators are seen as good. Many of the promoted people still remain or get promoted even further up to do more damage.

Promotions are based on getting backing from managers and hopping on board initiatives that staff engineers or managers push. Each new set of staff engineers or managers disparages the work of the previous set and advocates for their own work. No one is willing to push back against what they say.

Levels are uneven with some staff or senior engineers/QA who are anything but that. Long time mediocre people are accumulating. Some title inflation for new hires.

The attempt to make the culture more innovative is not working because the people who enforce and benefit from the culture are all still in positions of power.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep on acquiring companies.

review_title: Losing their way and not scaling well
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
Food

-Work/life balance

-Benefits
-There are a lot of chances for ownership and a ton of work still to be done.

-The people are great. Dropbox is incredible at finding a diverse range of high quality people.

-Diversity.

-The company culture is very inclusive.

-Still has the feel of a much smaller company.
cons:
People are churning out very fast in the past 9-12mo.

-Busy work is rewarded. A lot of people put out a ton of "work", but very little has impact. The volume of work is often used by people to vouch for promotion, bonuses, or transfer to higher roles in other teams.

-Reorgs. The company has had 6 internal re-orgs on teams I have been on since I joined. Imagine working on a project for 6 months, getting everything in line and then leadership decides to do something completely different. This makes it super hard for many people to actually accomplish something start to finish.

-A lot of teams are made up mostly by people who come in through the Dropbox Rotation Program out of school. I find that these teams are highly tribal, not open to criticism, and often do not do very high quality work but know how to play the system very well.

-Peer review process is hit or miss and a lot is open to what feedback your managers choose to include. Moreover if you move to another team you can often be "re-leveled" and miss out on promotions or career path opportunities.

-Due to there being so much work to be in certain divisions, a lot of time is wasted on things that have minor impact. On one hand employees milk this because it makes them look like they do a ton of informative work, but on the other hand if you look at things from the big picture we learn slowly and can't scale ideas well.
advice_to_mgmt:
Stop reorganizing divisions every few months.

-Invest more in data quality and analytics..

-Stop letting relatively inexperienced or junior staff interview technical candidates with more experience. You miss out on so many amazing candidates because the interviewer is simply not on the candidate's skill or communication level.

-Tuck Shop is cool, but you should trend towards serving healthier options. It becomes patronizing after the initial awe wears off.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
Benefits and pay are truly excellent. There are generous stipends for transit, wellness, learning and development (books and conferences), and others. Dental, vision, and health are all covered. There is donation matching up to a $1000 per year, unlimited volunteer and paid time off (which, if you're daring enough to request, truly seems unlimited—I have yet to hear of someone's PTO request being declined), and if you're in an office with a Tuck Shop, world-class food served every day. You can gift Dropbox space to friends and family.

The culture values kindness and open-mindedness to a fault, and teams are given massive autonomy to work and ship as they see fit. This means you can have very different experiences depending on your team and manager. This also means if you see something broken, you're generally given the OK to go and fix it if you have the will.

There are company events throughout the year, including team offsites (I've been hiking, on a cruise, to an escape room, and to countless dinners and happy hours), guest speakers, parties, etc. Dropbox seems to spare no expense on events and travel, although I've heard it was even more extravagant in the past.
cons:
Dropbox lies squarely in the "ruinous empathy" quadrant of business culture. Promotions are measured by the number of friends you make, not the results you achieve, which results in decision making by committee and projects that lag on for months at a time because nobody is willing to take ownership or say "no." At the same time, projects spanning 6+ months of research, design, and engineering can be derailed by the opinion of a single manager in the pursuit of "perfect" rather than "better".

Staff lack a clear vision for Dropbox. Milquetoast strategy updates and new opportunities receive endless bravado but when it comes to actual execution there's little follow-through. Meanwhile, the core Dropbox product continues to suffer from longstanding problems like convoluted sharing and horrendously slow performance.

We use Dropbox Paper, our own docs offering, for absolutely everything—from project management to calendaring to to-do lists to meeting notes. What results is total chaos. There is no sane way to organize docs, which get produced at an astounding rate: product managers regularly compose dozens of new Paper docs in any given week. There is no way we would organize ourselves this way if we weren't so committed to using and abusing our own tool.

Simple bugfixes languish in backlogs for months or years without resolution. Abysmal developer tools and nonexistent analytics slow the company to a crawl. 

We talk a big talk about "designing a more enlightened way of working" (corporate thinkpieces go up on the blog every few weeks) but how can we hope to improve work for others when our own house is a mess?

All these issues aren't new, and they're well-known to anyone who has been in the organization for longer than a year. We will talk about them and collectively agree they need to be addressed, but for whatever reason, nothing ever seems to happen.
advice_to_mgmt:
LEAD. Where are you? From down on the ground, seems like you've tapped out. Commit to a direction and see it through. Hold people accountable for results and set real deadlines. Fix the basics.

Standardize from the top down. We aren't a startup anymore, but we still act like one. We need standard platforms and processes across the org for project management, hard requirements for shipping, easily accessible analytics for *all* teams, and a continuous, direct line of communication with customer success so we understand the real problems that users are facing, not the problems we make up for our user personas to face.

Treat remote offices as first-class citizens. There's a lot of thrash that most likely goes unnoticed in SF. Check in to see how people are doing.

Pursue diversity more aggressively. And no, this doesn't mean just hiring more white women. We aren't doing well. Start with staff.

Even though we work in a satellite office (the HQ is in San Francisco) they are very careful to ensure that we maintain that environment that makes Dropbox special, as well as including everyone and being very transparent so that we don't end up feeling like a lonely island.

If you are lucky enough to work in the SF office, then you have your own restaurant with options crafted by a Michelin star chef. We also have a fully stocked kitchen and full bar. We also have a lounge area complete with Xbox One & Sega (old school), full band set-up, pool table, foosball, ping pong table and lots of different working spaces for any kind of work environment requested.

The transparency here is amazing, and if you have an idea or want to try something new out, I've been met with "yes" every time. Which is amazing and can offer up unlimited career progression, just don't be afraid to get in and get your hands dirty and get 'er done.

All that glitters isn't gold. Despite the glitz of the perks, many people at Dropbox are really unhappy. This is due to several things:
- Bad managers. Like, really bad. Very little training offered to new managers, and the company does not take action on managers who are consistently rated poorly or who have a lot of turnover on their team.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
Dropbox is making the transition from a startup to a real company. And they're doing it in an audacious way: make something people want, charge them for it, and sell it to millions of people. There's no "capture a fraction of the transaction cost" or "throw ads at people to extract value from something they'd like to get for free" here. It's a very clear, "make something people want enough that they'll pay you for it" business model. And as a maker, that's an exciting place to be.

The level of vertical integration (buy electricity, server components, and dark fiber/sell to mom and pop consumers) is the kind of thing you only expect to see from the phone company, or maybe Google or Amazon. Certainly not from a company with a couple hundred engineers. On a day-to-day basis, that means that the impact any particular engineer can have is HIGH.

The overall philosophy at Dropbox seems to be, "hire the best people you can find, and give them the freedom to do their thing." On the engineering side, this means the team is friendly, smart, and eager to help each other, making it a great place to learn.

That same philosophy applies outside of engineering, as well. Take the tuck shop (cafe), for example: Chef Brian and Chef Danny have hired great talent and given them the latitude to be creative, and as a result Dropbox has the best company food I've come across. My friends at Google love coming to Dropbox for lunch because the food is such a treat.
cons:
Dropbox is making the transition from a startup to a real company. And that means having the downsides of both a startup and a real company.

The real company downsides are pretty familiar: there's not as much openness as at a small company, you can get stuck with a lousy manager or on a project that gets canned, there's things you can't know and hoops you have to jump through for confidentiality/strategy/compliance reasons, etc.

The small company downsides are also real: your stock is monopoly money, there's a lot of uncertainty, and if you get stuck with a lousy manager, there might not be the systems in place to deal with it.

My biggest concern personally is that leveling and career progression seems fairly haphazard. Reviews have happened about twice a year since 2014, and every single review cycle has used a different set of criteria. And they're developing a new one for this fall's reviews. On some level, the things that make you a good engineer are universal across evaluation frameworks, but on another (e.g. does the system emphasize how well you facilitate other teams' work or how well your team executes its own tasks) it can make a pretty substantial difference.

- The perks are great. It's nice to not have to worry about food, and the health benefits are better than in most companies I've seen. 
- The office location is in the heart of downtown and the building has a great rooftop deck and gym in the basement.
cons:
For enterprise sales, you are promised high multipliers coming into the company, while less than 10% of the AEs on the enterprise team made their quota in 2015, so very few people ever reach these supposed numbers and most end up making less than they did before they came to Dropbox. The MM reps have the same quota whether their territory is NYC or Kansas (they consider a knowledge worker in one state equivalent to another) so quota achievement in that group is almost entirely based on whether you get a good territory. 
- The senior sales management in Austin is the worst I have ever worked with in my career. Countless sales females who were working in Austin have left the company, moved to other offices, or switched teams to get away from it. To date, there are no female sales managers in Austin and any female who could have been promoted, but who has disagreed with them, has been run off, leaving only newly hired people to choose from. 
- Inexperienced people in the company are given authority and power to do things they should not be allowed to do, i.e. the territories for the entire sales team were cut by someone 1-2 years out of school with no background in finance or consulting. 
- There is a clear lack of communication and coordination between teams in and around sales, which leads to a lot of confusion and course correction from week to week. It's hard to focus on selling when you have to keep track of so many things outside sales that affect your day to day. 
- The focus from the company is on the "wedding not the marriage" when it comes to sales. They do everything to help bring you in the door, but once there, there is little done towards retaining top talent which has led to an exodus of some of the best sales reps over the past months. 

Overall, know what you're getting into when joining Dropbox. There are still good people here and if you can find a good manager, you can create an enjoyable work environment. Unfortunately, with the senior sales management currently in Austin, I would recommend the other offices over this one, especially as a female.

review_title: Amazing culture, ridiculously talented people, has not won yet
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
The culture is governed by a set of values that is pervasive and has buy in from the employees. There is ownership in the work and it's easy to feel bought into what the company is trying to accomplish. There is a strong sense of community outside of work. The culture promotes continuous learning and provides the resources to do so; for instance, if someone wanted to learn how to code, play a new instrument, or learn a new language, it's very easy to do so at work. There is an interest group for pretty much anything you can think of, from soccer to poker to smash bros to Taylor Swift, which makes it easy to meet others and keep hobbies active.
- The talent bar has managed to stay incredibly high despite the increase in company size. There is probably no other group of 1,000+ individuals working on the same product as smart and talented as the team at Dropbox. Even though everyone is insanely smart and accomplished, people are unbelievably down to earth, approachable, and nice. In a recent internal survey of what it meant to be 'Dropboxy', humble was the most cited response by far.
- Have personally not had issues with work / life balance, but some individuals have probably had unfortunate experiences. I feel the company provides enough ownership and responsibility that one has control over work schedule and cadence, leading to much more predictability in hours. Even if I have a lot of work, I can still make plans on any day of the week, honor them, and finish up afterward from home if necessary. Increased ownership also means I'm directing my work more, so I don't find myself re-doing work unnecessarily. Only times I've worked longer hours are because I've wanted to do so on my own accord.
- Business is strong. A lot of external criticism regarding valuation and how well the business is actually doing, but company is on a growth trajectory most companies wish they could ever experience. Senior executive bench is stacked (COO, CFO, VPs); Dropbox has managed to bring in incredibly impressive individuals who've accomplished a lot at other companies.
- Compensation and perks are benchmarked to be among the top in the valley. Food is definitely the best in the valley, and probably of any corporate environment in the world.
cons:
Regarding point above on business being strong, Dropbox cannot say it has won. Cloud storage / collaboration space is very competitive with giants like Microsoft and Google wanting a piece. Company appears to lack a sense of urgency given success to date, but needs to keep pushing forward to sustain growth.
- To maintain extremely positive culture, a sub-culture of conflict aversion seems to have developed. Leads to some group think.
- Related to above, company has a hard time with having difficult conversations and making difficult decisions. More prevalent in inexperienced decision makers who want every piece of information and unanimous decision making, instead of just making a call.
- As company scales, increased emphasis is placed on processes and planning, which can make things feel more bureaucratic and progress is being made at a slower pace than it could be.
advice_to_mgmt: Need to establish an unambiguous product strategy. My impression is many teams are not 100% sure how to prioritize work because they're unsure what they're supposed to be prioritizing for.

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time
pros: More than generous compensation and perks.
cons:
Everyone at Dropbox spends a lot of time telling themselves and each other how great it is to work there, and not enough time making it a great place to work.

- Whenever Dropbox makes a public announcement, employees are encouraged to the point of cajoled into leaving positive comments and favorable reviews on public forums with personal accounts ("Don't forget to upvote the announcement on Hackernews! But don't do it on the office wifi because that can trigger a spam alert...", etc).
- Troubling company value: We not I. This means that you should put Dropbox before your own personal wellbeing. Employees that make personal sacrifices for the benefit of the company are deified at the all hands meeting.
- Cross-functional communication or collaboration is effectively impossible without the involvement of a manager or three, as everyone is worried only about completing their own sprint goals. The "start-up mindset" is useless for a 1000+ person corporate entity.
- Interviews and hire decisions are conducted in a very haphazard and non-transparent way, with more than a few interviewees mysteriously turned away after a consensus "hire" decision. 
- If you're not a 22 year old, male, Stanford/MIT/Carnegie Mellon grad or a Facebook/Google alumn, prepare to feel very out of place and marginalized.
- Good work goes unacknowledged unless you are a relentless self-promoter or part of the in-crowd. With respect to code, quantity counts more than quality.
- Working hours regularly extend late into the night. I once tried to hold a 10:30 am meeting, and was told by a manager that this was "ridiculously early". Another time, I came into the office around 11 PM to pick up something that I had forgotten, and it was half full with people working and playing video games.
- Consequently, important business decisions get made during non-standard business hours, so when you come into work at 9 AM, you'll be greeted with an inbox full of new decisions, priorities and tasks.
- Heavy drinking is commonplace at most official and non-official company functions, and opting-out is seen as being "not part of the team". When many of your coworkers/managers end up at a bachelor party in Vegas, you will definitely hear about it at your next sprint planning meeting.
- Gossip-y. Again, if you're not in the in-crowed, you will be at its mercy.
-- This extends to HR. Do not share anything with HR that you don't want your manager and coworkers to also know.
- Rampant entitlement among employees. At dinner, one can frequently overhear such gems as "I'm too good for MUNI" and "Well it's easier for women to get hired, so that's probably why she was hired and not X (male person)".

Summarily, I felt that my career prospects would be limited as I was not part of the in-crowd, and unwilling to put in 60 hour weeks among less-than-desirable company. Ultimately though, Dropbox will continue to make buckets of money despite its troubling culture.

pros:
We focus on making the users life simpler and are trying to build a company that makes money because people pay us for what we offer, which is fairly unique in this day and age where most companies are focused on eyeballs to show ads.

We also solve challenging technical problems at scale both on the client (large amounts of personal data, in fast low resource clients, across a wide variety of platforms) and in our backend (large amounts of data, mostly unique per user). And when we build things we strive to build them correctly. Both because we're protecting data that is precious to our users, but also because we believe in quality and things just working for our users.

Benefits, time off, etc are all world class; but they're not the reason you should work here. The reason to work here is the focus on the user, the focus on quality, and solving hard engineering problems.
cons: The company is growing fast, and growing causes pain. review_title: Doesn't get much better than this -
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
Dropbox is truly one-of-a-kind place. When I was looking at tech companies, I was fortunate enough to be considered at places like Google, Facebook, and Amazon. Frankly, I didn't really seriously consider Dropbox until I received a call from a recruiter who had received my resume, and wanted to set up a phone screen. Wow - was I missing out on the best place to work in the valley right now. Upon receiving an offer here, there was zero question or doubt in my mind about accepting - Google could have come back with all the compensation in the world, but the opportunity to help build the next big thing at Dropbox was unparalleled. Here are a few of the reasons I decided to join, and love working here:
- There's no bureacracy at this place. Sure, we are still small-ish (about 700 now, about 500 when I started), but things just get DONE. There isn't a lot of 'approval' and 'review' for little changes that need to be made or for ideas that folks want to give a whirl. Such a refreshing process.
- The leadership team is phenomenal. There is no hiding behind walls (literally - even our co-founders sit in our open-space desk arrangement amongst everyone else) and they are available and accessible. Exec. team is super grounded and humble, and this allows us to grow in a healthy way, because egos don't get you anywhere here.
- The opportunity that is available is the KEY to joining this place. If you are willing to work super hard and get your hands dirty, you will be able to join products, drive initiatives, and actually get stuff done. Your work doesn't feel menial -it feels like you are actually helping to grow this place.
- The PERKS are just as fabulous (if not more) than any other hot tech company. Why? Because we are still growing, so the perks feel super customized and high touch. There is plenty of pitching myself here because I wonder how I landed this gig. It's a dream.
cons:
It's honestly so fun and social that I sometimes worry about my non-Dropbox life and if I am giving it enough attention. By all means, it is my decision to stay for dinner, happy hours, and other social activities, and there is no pressure to do these things, but they have created such a great environment here that it is easy to get roped in and abandon other parts of your life. Disclaimer: Dropbox is NOT a place that does not support work/life balance. Everyone gets to choose how involved they become!
- Some growing pains. As we hire like crazy this year, we will (and are) experiencing slight growing pains like having the company split into different buildings (they are a 5 minute walk apart, but still changes the dynamic). Inevitable, though, at a company that is succeeding.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you are doing, and don't sell out to politics as we grow! Also, as we continue the push to make Dropbox an exceptionally diverse place to work, let's not forget this initiative and embed this in to our company values long-term.

review_title: Great opportunity to learn and build out your skill set - especially considering the growth path of the company
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
The cofounders really care about the people here, and you see this on a daily basis. The decision making process at the exec level is really transparent, so you get to learn a lot on a broader company level (what our 3/6/12 month goals are, why they are that way, what we could of done better in the last year, etc.). There are times when I feel like part of my job is getting paid to go to business school, how awesome is that?

There are a lot of great people here to help teach you "stuff". (Sorry for the engineers reading this part, I'll let our eng gals and guys speak more to that sphere). You want to learn Photoshop? SQL, Hive, Python, how our infrastructure works? It is nice to know that you can never stop learning. 

Especially for those of us early in their career, a culture of learning and getting connected with the right people and teams is crucial. It is also nice to know that it is at a company that is not yet 3, 5, 10, or 30 thousand people... Lots of opportunities, lots of growth ahead, easier to navigate and learn from different parts of the business, etc. Not trying to say big corporations don't have great opportunities, just that they have different ones.

I could go on and on about perks. But I won't. Besides the Tuck Shop... their food is legendary. Also, +1 to the kickass office space... and the kickass office team! 

What else? Truthfully, some of my closest friends in San Francisco are dropboxers, in and outside of the office. It's also important to note that many of my professional mentors and leaders that I look up to are also here. It's nice to have that spectrum of choice :)

My leads ("managers") have all exposed me to different expertise and ways of thinking. I've reported to a cofounder of a startup we've acquired, a military vet with an MBA, a consultant that worked in London and Russia, and a former professional Drummer that played on stage at Lollapalooza.

I learn from sales people, I learn from engineers, I learn from designers, I learn from our COO, our CFO, our cofounders, and just about every other single person at this company. I wake up relatively stoked to come in to the office and feel satisfied enough to leave at a reasonable hour. I take vacations. Sometimes I leave at 4pm, sometimes 5 or 6, sometimes 9. I enjoy my weekends. I have built solid skills set entirely at work. I don't drink the Koolaid, it is just really hard not to be happy here when you work with fun, smart, and friendly people.

One of the best pieces of advice I received growing up was "surround yourself with people that are smarter than you". We have leaders in design, engineering, and business. My teammates and friends at Dropboxer never cease to impress me. Sometimes, I wish it was me that felt like Einstein, but for now I am completely content with feeling like Curious George. The efforts and outputs of my peers both push me and remind me that there is plenty more to learn, and PLENTY more to do.
cons:
Structure and career pathing isn't *yet* as defined as it would be at a Google or Facebook. But what do you expect? We are currently ~700 employees and last year at this time we were ~250 - of course there are going to be some growing pains. 

It is something currently being addressed at a company wide level and the leadership knows how important it is as we grow, so I don't imagine it being a bullet point in this section 6-12 months (max) from now.

review_title: Working at Dropbox makes me happy every day.
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
Dropbox is constantly changing, open to adapting to new good ideas and changing course to keep on a winning track. I've worked a lot of places where senior leaders want you to sit down, shut up, and do your job - that's exactly the opposite of things here. There are so many opportunities to step up and help make things better.

--I consistently find my co-workers to be unbelievably smart, incredibly driven, and entirely dedicated to company success over the long term. Everyone 'gets it' across the whole company, from sales to recruiting to engineering. It makes it fun to problem solve as a team.

--We're working on some incredibly tough, highly motivating problems. Few companies deal with the amount of data and global footprint we manage and seek to expand on a daily basis. It's an exciting, big challenge, and invigorating every day.

--The culture and company morale are outstanding, buoyed by a great team combined with delightful daily experiences like the Tuck Shop or awesome new Dropbox swag. It always feels like people are happy and excited to be here, and that sentiment is highly infectious.
cons:
The constant change can be unnerving for some people, especially the change on the constantly reorganizing business / sales side. I enjoy reconfiguring as needed so we can best tackle the challenges ahead, but this can also lead to many feeling we lack of stability in daily processes or job responsibilities. Some people find the change overwhelming at times.

--Dropbox is incredibly generous with benefits and equity, but a bit cheaper when it comes to annual salaries. It's still big-risk, big-reward over here, which does keep us all invested in winning big in the long term.
advice_to_mgmt: The senior leadership of Dropbox sent out an email to the whole company asking for our thoughts on company priorities a few weeks ago. I sent all my suggestions in then!

review_title: Incredible company to work for - if you get an offer, take it!
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
Teammates are incredibly smart, motivated, mission-oriented and humble. It is a joy to come to work every day!
- Level of ownership over your work or projects is unparalleled, in my experience. I have had the opportunity to work on impactful projects within my own team as well as cross-functionally, and if you're on a project, you have a voice at the table - no matter how senior-level that table may be.
- Senior management is very transparent - open Q&A every week, board meeting reviews, company-wide updates, etc. I feel like I know what is going on with other teams and at a company level. Our exec team trusts us to the point of being able to share a lot of information (product development, financials, etc.) that might be kept confidential at other/larger companies.
- My lead gives me support and advice rather than micro-managing or delegating work to me... I essentially get to "be my own boss" on a day-to-day basis. That is partially a function of how my team is structured, but it also reflects our belief that you are going to be inherently driven to do your best work and don't need to be micro-managed.
- Tuck Shop (our cafe). Enough said. 
- Competitive compensation and great benefits (gym, cell phone, Caltrain, commuter benefit, shuttle in the city, 401k match, charitable donation match, etc.).
cons: We may have tripled in size in the past year and a half, but we are still a start-up in many respects. Things change fast, and your responsibilities are often a level or two higher than your role may indicate. That's a great opportunity to gain experience quickly, but a promotion that reflects how much you've taken on may lag behind a bit (and work-life balance may suffer in the near-term). That said, addressing these issues are something that our management team and People Ops is actively working on.
advice_to_mgmt: Recognize and reward your top performers and keep the company as transparent as it has been historically!
